title: Nottingham
text:
Three young sisters have been praised for safely escaping their house when a tumble dryer caught fire over the weekend.

Carter, Lucy and Katie Fitzpatrick, aged 19, 14 and 12 respectively, were at home in Brunel Avenue, Newthorpe, on Saturday night when they noticed the dryer was "melting".

They all got out of the house, with the dog, and alerted the emergency services and a neighbour.

BBC

When their parents, Anna (pictured below with Katie) and Sean Fitzpatrick, returned to their home from a meal out, they saw the fire engine outside their house.

Mrs Fitzpatrick said: "You could smell it as soon as you opened the car door. The rain was absolutely driving as well so it wasn't the most pleasant of times but we knew the children were safe."

She said the children had all been taught what to do in case of a fire.

BBC

Nottinghamshire Fire and Rescue Service said the swift actions of the children "undoubtedly saved themselves and more damage to the property".

The cause of the fire is believed to be a fault with the tumble dryer's control panel. Amazingly, all the washing inside the machine wasn't damaged.

The family is currently staying in their caravan until more is known about the damage caused to the house.
